    • Penalized Precision Matrix Estimation in grasps

Penalized Precision Matrix Estimation in grasps

Source: vignettes/pen_est.Rmd
pen_est.Rmd

Preliminary

Consider the following setting:

  • Gaussian graphical model (GGM) assumption:
    The data Xn×dX_{n \times d} consists of independent and identically distributed samples X1,…,Xn∼Nd(μ,Σ)X_1, \dots, X_n \sim N_d(\mu,\Sigma).

  • Disjoint group structure:
    The dd variables can be partitioned into disjoint groups.

  • Goal:
    Estimate the precision matrix Ω=Σ−1=(ωij)d×d\Omega = \Sigma^{-1} = (\omega_{ij})_{d \times d}.

Sparse-Group Estimator

$$ \hat{\Omega}(\lambda,\alpha,\gamma) = {\arg\min}_{\Omega \succ 0} \Bigl\{ - \log\det(\Omega) + \operatorname{tr}(S\Omega) + P_{\lambda,\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega) \Bigr\}, $$ Pλ,α,γ(Ω)=αPλ,γindividual(Ω)+(1−α)Pλ,γgroup(Ω), P_{\lambda,\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega) = \alpha P^\text{individual}_{\lambda,\gamma}(\Omega) + (1-\alpha) P^\text{group}_{\lambda,\gamma}(\Omega), Pλ,γindividual(Ω)=∑i,jpλ,γ(|ωij|), P^\text{individual}_{\lambda,\gamma}(\Omega) = \sum_{i,j} p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\vert\omega_{ij}\vert), Pλ,γgroup(Ω)=∑g,g′pλ,γ(‖Ωgg′‖F). P^\text{group}_{\lambda,\gamma}(\Omega) = \sum_{g,g^\prime} p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\Vert\Omega_{gg^\prime}\Vert_F).

where:

  • S=n−1∑i=1n(Xi−X‾)(Xi−X‾)⊤S = n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^n (X_i-\bar{X})(X_i-\bar{X})^\top is the empirical covariance matrix.

  • λ≥0\lambda \geq 0 is the global regularization parameter controlling overall shrinkage.

  • α∈[0,1]\alpha \in [0,1] is the mixing parameter controlling the balance between element-wise and block-wise penalties.

  • γ\gamma is the additional parameter controlling the curvature and effective degree of nonconvexity of the penalty.

  • Pλ,α,γ(Ω)P_{\lambda,\alpha,\gamma}(\Omega) is a generic bi-level penalty template that can incorporate convex or non-convex regularizers while preserving the intrinsic group structure among variables.

  • Pλ,γindividual(Ω)P^\text{individual}_{\lambda,\gamma}(\Omega) is the element-wise individual penalty term.

  • Pλ,γgroup(Ω)P^\text{group}_{\lambda,\gamma}(\Omega) is the block-wise group penalty term.

  • pλ,γ(⋅)p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\cdot) is a penalty function parameterized by λ\lambda and γ\gamma.

  • Ωgg′\Omega_{gg^\prime} is the submatrix of Ω\Omega with the rows from group gg and columns from group g′g^\prime.

  • The Frobenius norm ‖Ω‖F\Vert\Omega\Vert_F is defined as ‖Ω‖F=(∑i,j|ωij|2)1/2=[tr(Ω⊤Ω)]1/2\Vert\Omega\Vert_F = (\sum_{i,j} \vert\omega_{ij}\vert^2)^{1/2} = [\operatorname{tr}(\Omega^\top\Omega)]^{1/2}.

Note: For convex penalties, the parameter γ\gamma is not required, and the penalty function pλ,γ(⋅)p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\cdot) simplifies to pλ(⋅)p_\lambda(\cdot).

Penalties

  1. Lasso: Least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (Tibshirani 1996; Friedman, Hastie, and Tibshirani 2008)

pλ(ωij)=λ|ωij|.p_\lambda(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert.

  1. Adaptive lasso (Zou 2006; Fan, Feng, and Wu 2009)

pλ,γ(ωij)=λ|ωij|vij, p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\frac{\vert\omega_{ij}\vert}{v_{ij}}, where V=(vij)d×d=(|ω̃ij|γ)d×dV = (v_{ij})_{d \times d} = (\vert\tilde{\omega}_{ij}\vert^\gamma)_{d \times d} is a matrix of adaptive weights, and ω̃ij\tilde{\omega}_{ij} is the initial estimate obtained using penalty = "lasso".

  1. Atan: Arctangent type penalty (Wang and Zhu 2016)

pλ,γ(ωij)=λ(γ+2π)arctan(|ωij|γ),γ>0. p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda(\gamma+\frac{2}{\pi}) \arctan\left(\frac{\vert\omega_{ij}\vert}{\gamma}\right), \quad \gamma > 0.

  1. Exp: Exponential type penalty (Wang, Fan, and Zhu 2018)

pλ,γ(ωij)=λ[1−exp(−|ωij|γ)],γ>0. p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\left[1-\exp\left(-\frac{\vert\omega_{ij}\vert}{\gamma}\right)\right], \quad \gamma > 0.

  1. Lq (Frank and Friedman 1993; Fu 1998; Fan and Li 2001)

pλ,γ(ωij)=λ|ωij|γ,0<γ<1. p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert^\gamma, \quad 0 < \gamma < 1.

  1. LSP: Log-sum penalty (Candès, Wakin, and Boyd 2008)

pλ,γ(ωij)=λlog(1+|ωij|γ),γ>0. p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\omega_{ij}) = \lambda\log\left(1+\frac{\vert\omega_{ij}\vert}{\gamma}\right), \quad \gamma > 0.

  1. MCP: Minimax concave penalty (Zhang 2010)

pλ,γ(ωij)={λ|ωij|−ωij22γ,if |ωij|≤γλ,12γλ2,if |ωij|>γλ.γ>1. p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\omega_{ij}) = \begin{cases} \lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert - \dfrac{\omega_{ij}^2}{2\gamma}, & \text{if } \vert\omega_{ij}\vert \leq \gamma\lambda, \\ \dfrac{1}{2}\gamma\lambda^2, & \text{if } \vert\omega_{ij}\vert > \gamma\lambda. \end{cases} \quad \gamma > 1.

  1. SCAD: Smoothly clipped absolute deviation (Fan and Li 2001; Fan, Feng, and Wu 2009)

pλ,γ(ωij)={λ|ωij|if |ωij|≤λ,2γλ|ωij|−ωij2−λ22(γ−1)if λ<|ωij|<γλ,λ2(γ+1)2if |ωij|≥γλ.γ>2. p_{\lambda,\gamma}(\omega_{ij}) = \begin{cases} \lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert & \text{if } \vert\omega_{ij}\vert \leq \lambda, \\ \dfrac{2\gamma\lambda\vert\omega_{ij}\vert-\omega_{ij}^2-\lambda^2}{2(\gamma-1)} & \text{if } \lambda < \vert\omega_{ij}\vert < \gamma\lambda, \\ \dfrac{\lambda^2(\gamma+1)}{2} & \text{if } \vert\omega_{ij}\vert \geq \gamma\lambda. \end{cases} \quad \gamma > 2.

Illustrative Visualization

Figure 1 illustrates a comparison of various penalty functions p(ω)p(\omega) evaluated over a range of ω\omega values. The main panel (right) provides a wider view of the penalty functions’ behavior for larger |ω|\vert\omega\vert, while the inset panel (left) magnifies the region near zero [−1,1][-1, 1].

Figure 1: Illustrative penalty functions.

Figure 2 displays the derivative function p′(ω)p^\prime(\omega) associated with a range of penalty types. The Lasso exhibits a constant derivative, corresponding to uniform shrinkage. For MCP and SCAD, the derivatives are piecewise: initially equal to the Lasso derivative, then decreasing over an intermediate region, and eventually dropping to zero, indicating that large |ω|\vert\omega\vert receive no shrinkage. Other non-convex penalties show smoothly diminishing derivatives as |ω|\vert\omega\vert increases, reflecting their tendency to shrink small |ω|\vert\omega\vert strongly while exerting little to no shrinkage on large ones.

Figure 2: Illustrative penalty derivatives.

Reference

Candès, Emmanuel J., Michael B. Wakin, and Stephen P. Boyd. 2008. “Enhancing Sparsity by Reweighted ℓ1\ell_1 Minimization.” Journal of Fourier Analysis and Applications 14 (5): 877–905. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00041-008-9045-x.
Fan, Jianqing, Yang Feng, and Yichao Wu. 2009. “Network Exploration via the Adaptive LASSO and SCAD Penalties.” The Annals of Applied Statistics 3 (2): 521–41. https://doi.org/10.1214/08-aoas215.
Fan, Jianqing, and Runze Li. 2001. “Variable Selection via Nonconcave Penalized Likelihood and Its Oracle Properties.” Journal of the American Statistical Association 96 (456): 1348–60. https://doi.org/10.1198/016214501753382273.
Frank, Lldiko E., and Jerome H. Friedman. 1993. “A Statistical View of Some Chemometrics Regression Tools.” Technometrics 35 (2): 109–35. https://doi.org/10.1080/00401706.1993.10485033.
Friedman, Jerome, Trevor Hastie, and Robert Tibshirani. 2008. “Sparse Inverse Covariance Estimation with the Graphical Lasso.” Biostatistics 9 (3): 432–41. https://doi.org/10.1093/biostatistics/kxm045.
Fu, Wenjiang J. 1998. “Penalized Regressions: The Bridge Versus the Lasso.” Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics 7 (3): 397–416. https://doi.org/10.1080/10618600.1998.10474784.
Tibshirani, Robert. 1996. “Regression Shrinkage and Selection via the Lasso.” Journal of the Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Methodological) 58 (1): 267–88. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.2517-6161.1996.tb02080.x.
Wang, Yanxin, Qibin Fan, and Li Zhu. 2018. “Variable Selection and Estimation Using a Continuous Approximation to the L0L_0 Penalty.” Annals of the Institute of Statistical Mathematics 70 (1): 191–214. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10463-016-0588-3.
Wang, Yanxin, and Li Zhu. 2016. “Variable Selection and Parameter Estimation with the Atan Regularization Method.” Journal of Probability and Statistics 2016: 6495417. https://doi.org/10.1155/2016/6495417.
Zhang, Cun-Hui. 2010. “Nearly Unbiased Variable Selection Under Minimax Concave Penalty.” The Annals of Statistics 38 (2): 894–942. https://doi.org/10.1214/09-AOS729.
Zou, Hui. 2006. “The Adaptive Lasso and Its Oracle Properties.” Journal of the American Statistical Association 101 (476): 1418–29. https://doi.org/10.1198/016214506000000735.
